Since I suspect that there is some misunderstanding going on with regards to my posts, let me clarify my views:
 
 There are treatments that qualify as torture and treatments that are simply harrassment. Traditional torture involves extreme forms of physical or mental pain. I also do not condone such traditional forms of torture. Harrassment is much milder and include such things as the typical "good cop - bad cop" routine used during criminal interrogations. As long as we don't have a bilateral agreement prohibiting such harrassment, I would condone any such milder techniques as long as they are effective and they are used on subjects that we have strong suspicions of knowing useful information. Between those two types of treatment lie a wide range of harsher and less harsh treatments. I don't have a good feeling where to place an ultimate moral line that we do not cross - which is why I was hoping to hear a discussion on such a point.

If that is the case, then I believe we should have the right to interrogate that prisoner, within bounds that are a limited by either bilateral agreement or an ultimate moral boundary (whichever is more lenient).
